comments:
This final clinical nursing course focuses on the integration and synthesis of scientific knowledge with clinical nursing practice and the development of the professional nursing role. Building on content from prior courses, students will develop an understanding of management of patient care from the perspective of the individual client and family to groups of clients and eventually to management of health care systems. Principles of leadership, accountability and change will be integrated throughout. The process of transition from the student role to that of the professional nurse will be facilitated through discussion of organizational systems, professional issues, mechanisms for evaluation of care and the role of the nurse as patient advocate and change agent. Students will select from several practice options for the clinical content of the course. Clinical seminar content will build on core content and will provide an exposure to advanced nursing concepts within the area of specialty practice. Application of conceptual models to clinical practice will be discussed and nursing research will be integrated throughout the course. Students will be assessed primarily by papers (for example, the Scope of Practice paper and Model of Nursing paper).

While several students thought that this course “broadened [their] perspective of what a nurse is responsible for,” most students did not enjoy this class and felt that it was a poor conclusion at the end of four years at nursing school. Many reported that the class itself was not “engaging” or “interactive,” as it was based mostly off of Power Point slides. Some students wished that there had been more case study analysis and group activities. The majority of students felt there was too much emphasis on health care policy and not enough instruction on legal/ethical issues and staff nurse issues. The foremost complaint was the lack of NCLEX review; many students lamented that as seniors, as they hoped for more preparation on the NCLEX examination in this final nursing course. Students also complained about the length of this course; many noted that the 3-hour lectures could be condensed into 1.5-hour classes.

This course was primarily taught by Professor Rogers and Professor Polsky. One student “greatly appreciated the instructors and their effort.” However, most felt dissatisfied with the teachers. Many students felt that assignments were graded based on “the professor’s personal opinions rather than objective reasons.” Some noted that the lecturers often read off the slides without much interaction with the students.

Many students had problems with the grade distribution and the assignments of this course. Several students noted that grading was “inconsistent,” “vague,” and “too strict.” One student said that “grading rubrics were not followed and large point values were removed without explanation.” Another student noted that “assignments...did not adequately evaluate [their] effort and knowledge learned from this course.” Prerequisities for this class include NURS 321, 322, 340 and 341. The corequisite for this class is NURS 371. This course is for second semester senior Nursing students.
